Abstract: Generative models have emerged as a pivotal tool across various scientific disciplines, offering robust frameworks for simulating complex systems and enhancing decision-making processes. This interdisciplinary perspective explores the integration of generative models with agent-based models, emphasizing their utility in experimental design and simulation. The study delves into the application of particle filters for model evaluation, providing a comprehensive approach to assessing model performance and goodness-of-fit. By bridging theoretical constructs with practical applications, this research highlights the versatility of generative models in capturing dynamic phenomena and informing strategic decisions. The synthesis of methodologies from diverse fields underscores the potential of generative models to innovate experimental paradigms and optimize decision-making strategies. This work aims to foster a deeper understanding of the role of generative models in advancing scientific inquiry and their implications for future research directions.
